newsitem.title: VIETNAM: Vietnam steel output hits record, glut emerges.
newsitem.headline: Vietnam steel output hits record, glut emerges.

text.p: Vietnam has produced a record 1.6 million tonnes of steel this year, a threefold increase from 1995, the official Vietnam News Agency (VNA) said on Monday.

VNA quoted Ho Nghia Dung, director of the state-owned Vietnam Steel Corporation (VSC), as saying that an industry master plan was targeting output of 2.5-3.0 million tonnes by the turn of the century and 7.5-8.0 million by 2010.
The increase in steel output will go some way to meeting domestic demand, which has been boosted by a construction boom.

Vietnam imported 800,000 tonnes of steel in 1995 and, according to a recent newspaper report it had matched that level by the end of October this year despite a government-imposed curb on sales of steel from abroad.
However, the semi-official Vietnam Investment Review said last month that a glut of steel in the domestic market, largely the result of cheap imports, had begun to push production lower.
It said more than 400,000 tonnes of steel was sitting in store houses, more than half of it stock held by the VSC.

"Though the government banned steel imports in March 1996, the market is still saturated because of surplus and breaches of the ban," the weekly said, adding that steel producers in Vietnam had been obliged to sell at "war prices".
It said the steel industry was also faced with a downturn in new construction, which has emerged because some recent hotel and office complex projects have not performed as well as expected.
